question.text: \(\lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\left[1-\tan \left(\frac{x}{2}\right)\right][1-\sin x]}{\left[1+\tan \left(\frac{x}{2}\right)\right][\pi-2 x]^{3}}\) is equal to

solution.text:
\(\lim _{x \rightarrow \frac{\pi}{2}} \frac{\tan \left(\frac{\pi}{4}-\frac{x}{2}\right)(1-\sin x)}{(\pi-2 x)^{3}}\)
Let, \(x=\frac{\pi}{2}+y\)
\(\Rightarrow \lim _{y \rightarrow 0}=\frac{\tan \left(\frac{-y}{2}\right)(1-\cos y)}{(-2 y)^{3}}\)
\(=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{-\tan \frac{y}{2} \cdot 2 \sin ^{2} \frac{y}{2}}{(-8) y^{3}}=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{32} \frac{\tan \frac{y}{2}}{\left(\frac{y}{2}\right)} \cdot\left[\frac{\sin \frac{y}{2}}{\frac{y}{2}}\right]^{2}\)
\(=\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{32} \times \frac{\tan \frac{y}{2}}{\left(\frac{y}{2}\right)} \cdot\left(\lim _{y \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin \frac{y}{2}}{\frac{y}{2}}\right)^{2}\)
\(\because \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\tan x}{x}=1\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{32} \times 1 \times 1^{2}\)
\(=\frac{1}{32}\)

question.text: The value of \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\cos ^{3}(\sin x)}{\sin x \sin (\sin x) \cos (\sin x)}\) is equal to

solution.text:
Let, \(\sin x=t\)
\(\Rightarrow \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\cos ^{3} t}{t \sin t \cos t}\)
\(\Rightarrow \lim _{t \rightarrow 0} \frac{(1-\cos t)}{t^{2}} \times\left(\frac{t}{\sin t}\right) \times \frac{\left(1+\cos t+\cos ^{2} t\right)}{\cos t}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{1}{2} \times 1 \times \frac{(1+1+1)}{1}=\frac{3}{2}\)

question.text: The value of \(\lim _{x \rightarrow-\infty} \frac{x^{2} \tan \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}{\sqrt{4 x^{2}-x+1}}\) is equal to

solution.text: \(\lim _{x \rightarrow-\infty} \frac{x \frac{\tan \left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}{\left(\frac{1}{x}\right)}}{-x \sqrt{4-\frac{1}{x}+\frac{1}{x^{2}}}}=\frac{1}{-\sqrt{4}}=-\frac{1}{2}\)

question.text: limx→0tanxtanx-sinxsinxx3x equals

solution.text:
Let, L=limx→0tanxtanx-sinxsinxx3x

=limx→0(tanx)321-(cosx)32x3/2·x2
  =132·limx→01-cos3xx2·11+(cos x)32 (Rationalizing)

=limx→01-cosxx2·1+cosx+cos2x·11+cosx32
  =12·121+1+1=34.

question.text: The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>cos</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mi>sin</mi><mo> </mo><mi>x</mi><mo> </mo><mi>cos</mi><mo> </mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math> is

solution.text:

=limx→0sin x22x2×1+cos x+cos2 xcos x2cos x=12×3=32

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mi>sin</mi><mo> </mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> exists and is equal to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo></math> then

=limx→03sin 3x3x+a+bx2x2
limit exists if
3+a=0
or a=-3
∴  L=limx→0sin 3x-3x+bx3x3=27limt→0sin t-tt3+b=0  (Putting 3x=t)=-276+b=0

or b=92

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> is a differentiable function such that <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>1</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>f</mi><mo>'</mo></msup><mfenced><mn>4</mn></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math>, then value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>-</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>1</mn></mfenced></mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfenced><mo>-</mo><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mn>4</mn></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math> is :-

limx→02x+1f1x2+x+14x3-2x+2f1x4-x2+2x+4

=f'12f'4=4 (Applying L' Hospital's Rule)

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mrow><mi>l</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mo>∞</mo></mrow></munder><mfenced><mrow><msqrt><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></msqrt><mo>-</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo></math> then equation of circle whose centre is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and radius <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn></math> unit is

solution.text:
limx→∞x2+x+2-ax-b=2

a=1;b=-32 required equation is (x-1)2+(y+3)2=1

question.text: For a positive integer <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math>, if <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mo>∞</mo></mrow></munder><mfenced><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo> </mo><mi>ln</mi><mfenced><mfrac><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>x</mi></mfrac></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>m</mi></mfrac></math>. Then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>m</mi></math> is

solution.text:
limx→∞x3 ln1+1x+x2-x2

x=1t

limt→0ln(1+t)t3+12t-1t2=limt→02 ln(1+t)+t2-2t2t3

=limt→02t-t22+t33-t44+…+t2-2t2t3

=limt→013-t4+t25…..=13=1 m⇒m=3.

=limn→∞5n6.25n-205n5.25n+7=-207 ∵limn→ ∞25n=0

question.text: The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>cos</mi><mn>15</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math> is equal to

solution.text:
limx→0ln2-cos15xln2sin3x+1

=limx→0ln1+1-cos15xln21+sin3x

=limx→01-cos15xsin3x2 (Applyinglimx→0ln1+xx=1) 

=limx→015x223x2  (using standard limit)

=12252×9=12.5

question.text: Let <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mo>:</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℝ</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℝ</mi></math> be a function defined as <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>sin</mi><mfenced><mfrac><mrow><mi>π</mi><mfenced close="]" open="["><mi>x</mi></mfenced></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>,</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">ℝ</mi></math>, where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math> is the greatest integer less than or equal to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math>. If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></munder><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced></math> exists, then the value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msubsup><mo>∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mn>4</mn></msubsup><mi>f</mi><mfenced><mi>x</mi></mfenced><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Given,

fx=asinπx2+2-x,a∈ℝ

Now given limx→-1fx exists,

So limx→-1+asinπx2+2-x=-a+2

And limx→-1-asinπx2+2-x=0+3=3

So, limx→-1fx exist when -a+2=3⇒a=-1

Now,

∫04fxdx=∫01fxdx+∫12fxdx+∫23fxdx+∫34fxdx

⇒∫04fxdx=∫01-sinπx2+2-xdx+∫12-sinπx2+2-xdx+∫23-sinπx2+2-xdx+∫34-sinπx2+2-xdx

=∫010+1dx+∫12-1+0dx+∫230-1dx+∫341-2dx

=1-1-1-1=-2

question.text: The integer \(n\) for which \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{(\cos x-1)\left(\cos x-e^{x}\right)}{x^{n}}\) is a finite nonzero number is

solution.text:
\(\frac{(\cos x-1)\left(\cos x-e^{x}\right)}{x^{n}}\)
\(\begin{aligned}
=\frac{1}{x^{n}}\left(\left(1-\frac{x^{2}}{2 !}+\frac{x^{4}}{4 !}-\ldots\right)-1\right)\left(\left(1-\frac{x^{2}}{2 !}+\frac{x^{4}}{4 !}-\ldots\right)\right.\\
\left.-\left(1+x+\frac{x^{2}}{2 !}+\frac{x^{3}}{3 !} \ldots\right)\right) \\
=\frac{1}{x^{n}}\left[\left(-\frac{x^{2}}{2 !}+\frac{x^{4}}{4 !}-\ldots\right)\left(-x-x^{2}-\frac{x^{3}}{3 !} \ldots\right)\right] \\
=\frac{-1}{x^{n-3}}\left[\left(-\frac{1}{2 !}+\frac{x^{2}}{4 !}-\ldots\right)\left(1+x+\frac{x^{2}}{3 !} \ldots\right)\right]
\end{aligned}\)
\(\therefore\) For \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{(\cos x-1)\left(\cos x-e^{x}\right)}{x^{n}}\) to exist as a nonzero number we must have \(n-3=0 \Rightarrow n=3\).

question.text: If the largest value of the <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mo>∞</mo></mrow></munder><msup><mfenced><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi></mfrac></mrow></mfenced><mfrac><mi>x</mi><mi>b</mi></mfrac></msup></math> where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>a</mi><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mi>b</mi></math> lies in the interval <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac><mo>,</mo><mo> </mo><mn>403</mn></mrow></mfenced></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>e</mi><mi>λ</mi></msup></math>, then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>λ</mi></math> equals

solution.text:
limx→∞1+axxb=elimx→∞xb1+ax-1

∵1∞ form ]

=eab=e403×51=e2015≡eλ⇒λ=2015.

question.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>Lim</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>→</mo><mo>∞</mo></mrow></munder><msup><mfenced><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfrac></mfenced><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>n</mi></mfrac></msup></math> is equal to

solution.text:
L=el

l=Limn→∞n2-1n2n2-3-2n2+n-12n2-n+1

=Limn→∞n21-1n2-n1-4nn·n22-1n+1n2=12

∴ L=e.

question.text: \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 2} \frac{3^{x}+3^{3-x}-12}{3^{-\frac{x}{2}}-3^{1-x}}\) is equal to

solution.text:
Let, \(3^{\frac{x}{2}}=t, x \rightarrow 2 \Rightarrow t \rightarrow 3\)
\(\begin{array}{l}
\lim _{t \rightarrow 3} \frac{t^{2 \frac{2}{t^{2}}}-12}{\frac{1}{t}-\frac{3}{t^{2}}}=\lim _{t \rightarrow 3} \frac{t^{4}+27-12 t^{2}}{t-3} \\
\lim _{t \rightarrow 3} \frac{\left(t^{2}-3\right)(t+3)(t-3)}{(t-3)}=6 \times 6=36
\end{array}\)

question.text: The value of \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{1+\tan x}{1+\sin x}\right)^{\frac{2}{\sin x}}\) is equal to

solution.text:
Let, \(f(x)=\frac{1+\tan x}{1+\sin x}\)
and \(g(x)=\frac{2}{\sin x}\)
Clearly, \(f(x) \rightarrow 1\) and \(g(x) \rightarrow \infty\) as \(x \rightarrow 0\)
\(\begin{array}{l}
\therefore \lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(\frac{1+\tan x}{1+\sin x}\right)^{\frac{2}{\sin x}}=e^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2}{\sin x}\left(\frac{1+\tan x}{1+\sin x}-1\right)} \\
{\left\{\text { using } \lim _{x \rightarrow a}[f(x)]^{g(x)}=e^{\lim _{x \rightarrow a} g(x)[f(x)-1]} \text { for } 1^{\infty} \text { form }\right\}} \\
{=e^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2}{\sin x}\left(\frac{\tan x-\sin x}{1+\sin x}\right)}=e^{\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2(1-\cos x)}{\cos x(1+\sin x)}}} \\
{=e^{0}=1}
\end{array}\)

question.text: The value of <math><mrow><mrow><munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></munder></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">cot</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ln</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow></math> is equal to

solution.text:
limx→0+⁡xcot⁡x+limx→0+⁡xln⁡x
=limx→0+⁡xtan⁡x+limx→0+⁡ln⁡x1x
=limx→0+⁡xtan⁡x+limx→0+⁡1x-1x2=1+limx→0+⁡-x
=1+0=1

question.text: The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mo>→</mo><mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">π</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow></munder><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi><mn>3</mn></mfrac></mfenced><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mfrac></math> (where,  <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mo>.</mo></mfenced></math> denotes the greaest integer function)

solution.text:
∵π6<1,
∴π6=0
∴limx→π2x2lnsin⁡x=0

question.text: The \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} x^{8}\left[\frac{1}{x^{3}}\right]\) (where \([x]\) is greatest integer function) is (Mark incorrect option)

solution.text:
Since \(x-1 \leq[x] \leq x\) for all \(x \in \mathbf{R}\) so
\(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{1}{x^{3}}-1 \leq\left[\frac{1}{x^{3}}\right] \leq \frac{1}{x^{3}} \\
\Rightarrow \quad x^{8}\left(\frac{1}{x^{3}}-1\right) \leq x^{5}\left[\frac{1}{x^{3}}\right] \leq x^{5} \text { for all } x
\end{array}\)
But \(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} x^{5}=0=\lim _{x \rightarrow 0}\left(x^{5}-x^{8}\right)\) so
\(\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} x^{8}\left[\frac{1}{x^{3}}\right]=0 \in \mathbf{I} \subseteq \mathbf{Q}\)

question.text: If <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup></mfrac></math> exists finitely, then the value of <math><mi>a</mi></math> is

solution.text:
limx→0sin⁡x2cos⁡x-ax⋅x2=limx→0sin⁡xx2cos⁡x-ax2
For this limit to exists finitely,
limx→02cos⁡x-ax2=finite
∴ It must be 00 form
∴ 2cos⁡0-a=0⇒a=2

question.text:
The value of limx→0sin⁡x35x is equal to

(where, . represents the greatest integer function)

solution.text:
5x-1<5x≤5x
sin⁡x35x-1⏟hx<sin⁡x35x⏟fx≤sin⁡x35x⏟gx
by sandwich theorem
∵ limx→0gx=limx→0hx=53
 ∴limx→0fx=53

question.text:
The value of the limit

limn→∞n21-cos1n1-cos1n1-cos1n.....∞ is

solution.text:
Let the given expression be y.

Then, y=limn→∞n2

1-cos1n1-cos1n1-cos1n

On putting 1n=θ ......∞

So that, n→∞⇒θ→0

Thus,

y=limθ→01θ2(1-cosθ)12+122+123+....to ∞

=limθ→01-cos θθ2

∵ 12+122+…∞=1

=limθ→∞2sin2 θ/2θ2

=limθ→02sin θ/2θ/22×14

=2·12·14=12

question.text: The value of <math><munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></math> is equal to (where <math><mfenced close="]" open="[" separators="|"><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> represents the greatest integer part of <math><mi>x</mi></math>)

solution.text:
Let fx=x+22x+32x+...+n2x12+22+32+...+n2

Now, we have,

fx≤x+22x+32x+...+n2x12+22+32+...+n2=x

and, fx>x-1+22x-1+32x-1+...+n2x-112+22+32+...+n2

=xΣn2-nΣn2=x-6n+12n+1 ∵x-1≤x<x, ∀x∈R

Thus, we have,

x-6n+12n+1<fx≤x

Now, we have,

limn→∞x-6n+12n+1=x  &  limn→∞x=x

Hence, by Sandwich Theorem, we have

limn→∞fx=x

question.text: Let <math><mi>α</mi><mo>,</mo><mi> </mi><mi>β</mi><mo>∈</mo><mi>R</mi></math> be such that <math><mrow><mrow><munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">tan</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>β</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">tan</mi></mrow><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo></math> then the value of <math><mn>5</mn><mi>β</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>α</mi></math> is :

solution.text:
limx→0⁡x2tan⁡αxβx-tan⁡2x=1→ limx→0⁡x2tan⁡αxβx-2x+2x33+22x515=1

→β=2 and 3α8=-1,

So, 5β+3α=2

concepts: when limit tends to 0 or finite number

question.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>sin</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>-</mo><mi>cos</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>4</mn></msup></mfrac></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Consider limx→0cos(sinx)-cosxx4  00 form

limx→02sinsinx+x2·sinx-sinx2x4

=limx→02sinsinx+x2sinx+x2sinx-sinx2x-sinx2×sinx+x2×x-sinx2×1x4

limx→02sinsinx+x2sinx+x2sinx-sinx2x-sinx2×x2-sin2x4x4

limx→02×x2-sin2x4x4  00 form     ∵ limt→0sintt=1

Applying L'Hospital's Rule,

limx→02×2x-2sinxcosx4·4x3=limx→02x-sin2x8x3     00 form

limx→02-2cos2x24x2  00 form

limx→04sin2x48x=16limx→0sin2x2x=16

question.text: The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mi>lim</mi><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>→</mo><mo>∞</mo></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mfenced close="]" open="["><mi>r</mi></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>r</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>.</mo><mo>+</mo><mfenced close="]" open="["><mrow><mi>n</mi><mi>r</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><msup><mi>n</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>,</mo></math> where <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi></math> is non-zero real number and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="]" open="["><mi>r</mi></mfenced></math> denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>r</mi><mo>,</mo></math> is equal to :

solution.text:
We know that r≤r<r+1

2r≤2r<2r+1

3r≤3r<3r+1

⋮  ⋮   ⋮

nr≤nr<nr+1

On adding all the above inequalities, we get

r+2r+…+nr≤r+2r+...+nr<r+2r+...nr+n

Using 1+2+3+...+n=nn+12, n∈N,

nn+12·r≤r+2r+...+nr<nn+12·r+n

⇒nn+12·rn2≤r+2r+...+nrn2<nn+12·r+nn2

Now, limn→∞n(n+1)·r2·n2=limn→∞n21+1n·r2·n2=r2

and limn→∞nn+12·r+nn2=limn→∞n21+1n·r+1n2·n2=r2

So, by Sandwich Theorem, we can conclude that

limn→∞r+2r+...+nrn2=r2.

question.text: The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mfrac><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mrow></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mi>tan</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Using expansion,
 limx→01+-x22+x442!+....-1-x22!+x24!-....x3x+x33+....
limx→01-1+-x22+x22+x48-x424+....x3x+x33+....
⇒18-124=112

question.text: If <math><munder><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mi></mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, then the value of <math><mn>272</mn><mfrac><mrow><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></math> is equal to

solution.text:
Using expansions, we get,
limx→0a1+x+x22!+x33!+..+b1-x22!+...+c+dxxx-x33!+.....2=3
limx→0a+b+c+a+dx+a-b2x2+a6x3+…x31-x23!+.....2=3
∵ in the denominator lowest power of x is 3
For the limit to be finite, the numerator should also have the least power of x as 3
∴a+b+c=0  ...1
a+d=0...2
a-b2=0...3
Now, a61=3⇒a=18
From 1,2,3, we get,

a=18, b=18, c=–36, d=–18
abdc3=-183-8183=18
